questions.article: Tabby Cat is an important work of Nihonga, or classical Japanese painting. Unlike Asai Chǔ, who adopted traditional European methods such as painting with oil on canvas, Takeuchi Seihu ______ traditional Japanese approaches. For instance, Takeuchi produced Tabby Cat by applying color pigments to a silk surface.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: distrusted

options.name: B
options.content: overlooked

options.name: C
options.content: embraced

options.name: D
options.content: released

questions.correct: embraced

questions.article: Domesticated thousands of years ago in South America, the chili pepper deviates structurally from the wild plant it is descended from. Maize (corn), another domesticated crop from the Americas, doesn’t closely resemble any wild plant, and genetic research only recently ______ its ancestor to be teosinte grass.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: expanded

options.name: B
options.content: revealed

options.name: C
options.content: encouraged

options.name: D
options.content: petitioned

questions.correct: revealed

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Anton Chekhov’s 1904 play The Cherry Orchard (translated by Julius West in 1916).

TROFIMOV: Believe me, Anya, believe me! I’m not thirty yet, I’m young, I’m still a student, but I have undergone a great deal! I’m as hungry as the winter, I’m ill. I’m shaken—and where haven’t I been—fate has tossed me everywhere!
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “undergone” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Uncovered.

options.name: B
options.content: Overlooked.

options.name: C
options.content: Experienced.

options.name: D
options.content: Related.

questions.correct: Experienced.

questions.article: Text corpora such as the International Corpus of English are enormous collections of electronically stored texts that can be used for empirical testing of hypotheses regarding the frequency of typical word usage. If one has a ______ that the word “last” has a high incidence in English, for example, an analysis of a corpus can support that hypothesis by showing that “last” is the fourth most commonly used adjective.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: supposition

options.name: B
options.content: scheme

options.name: C
options.content: synopsis

options.name: D
options.content: recognition

questions.correct: supposition

questions.article: Researchers have long hypothesized that woolly mammoths were hunted to extinction in North America by humans using spears with grooved tips known as Clovis points. One anthropologist set out to test this hypothesis. Using a mechanical spear-thrower, he launched spears with Clovis points into mounds of clay—substitutes for the animals’ large bodies. The projectiles generally penetrated only a few inches into the clay, an amount insufficient to have harmed most woolly mammoths. This led the anthropologist to conclude that hunters using spears with Clovis points likely weren’t the principal drivers of the extinction.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To argue for the significance of new findings amid an ongoing debate among researchers.

options.name: B
options.content: To discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the method used in an experiment.

options.name: C
options.content: To summarize two competing hypotheses and a major finding associated with each one.

options.name: D
options.content: To describe an experiment whose results cast doubt on an established hypothesis.

questions.correct: To describe an experiment whose results cast doubt on an established hypothesis.

questions.article: In what is now New Mexico, the Pueblo of Pojoaque operates the Poeh Cultural Center. Relying on traditional knowledge to guide the design of exhibits, this institution presents Pojoaque history and culture to the tribe’s citizens. The Tohono O’odham Nation, a tribe in Arizona, employs a similar strategy in its own cultural center. Both centers contrast with museums that aren’t Indigenous-led; when displaying Indigenous artifacts, such museums tend to anticipate mainly non-Indigenous audiences and rely on Euro-centric strategies for designing exhibits.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It outlines an early strategy for exhibit design used by one tribal cultural center, then explains a newer strategy used by a different tribal cultural center.

options.name: B
options.content: It discusses two cultural centers operated by tribes, then compares them with non-Indigenous institutions that present Indigenous exhibits.

options.name: C
options.content: It describes how tribal cultural centers designed exhibits of a particular set of artifacts, then analyzes how non-Indigenous Institutions designed exhibits of the same artifacts.

options.name: D
options.content: It examines how tribal citizens respond to exhibits at tribal cultural centers, then speculates how non-Indigenous audiences would respond to the same exhibits.

questions.correct: It discusses two cultural centers operated by tribes, then compares them with non-Indigenous institutions that present Indigenous exhibits.

questions.article:
Text 1
Duke University and the investment bank Citi are two of the many institutions offering training programs in entrepreneurship. But what results do such programs produce? In a study of engineering students in Canada, researchers Teresa Menzies and Joseph Paradi addressed this question and reported that participants who received entrepreneurial training showed high likelihood of creating new businesses.

Text 2
While studies of entrepreneurial training typically report positive results, a close look reveals widespread methodological shortcomings that could explain those findings. These studies are plagued by insufficient sample sizes, a lack of control groups, and failures to establish pretraining baselines for the measured attributes of participants.
questions.question: Based on the texts, the author of Text 2 would most likely want to know if Menzies and Paradi took steps to preclude which potential objection to the finding described in Text1?

options.name: A
options.content: The participants would have responded to the training differently if they had not known that they were participating in a study.

options.name: B
options.content: The participants would have shown high likelihood of creating new businesses regardless of whether they received the training.

options.name: C
options.content: The participants would have been less likely to show high likelihood of creating new businesses if the study sample size had been smaller.

options.name: D
options.content: The participants would have shown greater responsiveness to the training if the training sessions had lasted longer.

questions.correct: The participants would have shown high likelihood of creating new businesses regardless of whether they received the training.

questions.article: “Coyote” is an example of a loanword—that is, a word that originated in one language and was later adopted by another. The word came to English indirectly from coyote, the Spanish word for the wild canine species. Spanish had borrowed it from Nahuatl, an Indigenous language of Central Mexico, in which the word’s original form is coyote. “Llama” is also Indigenous in origin and entered English through Spanish. But in this case, the original source was Quechua, a language of South America, in which the word for the woolly farm animal is also llama.
questions.question: The author makes which point about the Spanish language?

options.name: A
options.content: It has borrowed words from Indigenous languages and contributed words to them.

options.name: B
options.content: It adopted Nahuatl and Quechua words in approximately equal numbers.

options.name: C
options.content: It has served as a medium through which Indigenous languages have influenced English.

options.name: D
options.content: Its contribution to English vocabulary roughly equals the collective contribution by Indigenous languages.

questions.correct: It has served as a medium through which Indigenous languages have influenced English.

questions.article: In Paraguay, use of solid fuel (e.g., coal, wood) as a share of total household fuel use fell by around 40 percent between 2000 and 2019; such shifts are typically explained by appeal to the energy ladder, a model holding that fuel choice is mediated mainly by household income (specifically, high-technology fuels displace solid fuels as incomes rise). Boukary Ouedraogo’s study of fuel use in Burkina Faso shows how reductive this model is, however: although income of course constrained fuel choice, several factors, including the type of cooking equipment available, influenced decisions.
questions.question: Based on the text, the author would most likely agree with which statement about household income?

options.name: A
options.content: It affects household fuel choice but not for the reasons assumed by the energy ladder model.

options.name: B
options.content: It can explain some but not all of the differences in fuel choice across households.

options.name: C
options.content: It constrains the amount of fuel households use but not the type of fuel they use.

options.name: D
options.content: It is often said to influence household fuel choice but actually does not.

questions.correct: It can explain some but not all of the differences in fuel choice across households.

questions.article: Claudine at School is a 1900 novel by Colette, originally written in French. The narrator is a fifteen-year-old girl living in a small, rural town. She presents herself as having a strong emotional attachment to the surrounding forests: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of Claudine at School most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “If I had a Mamma, I know very well that she would not have let me stay [in Montigny] twenty-four hours. But Papa—he doesn’t notice anything and doesn’t bother about me.”

options.name: B
options.content: “No small creatures in those great woods; no tall grasses; but beaten earth, now dry, and sonorous, now soft on account of the springs. Rabbits with white scats [tails] range through them and timid deer who run so fast that you can only guess their passage.”

options.name: C
options.content: “And then there are my favorites, the great woods that are sixteen and twenty years old. It makes my heart bleed to see one of those cut down.”

options.name: D
options.content: “Green meadows make rifts in [the woods] here and there, so do little patches of cultivation. But these do not amount to much, for the magnificent woods devour everything. As a result, this lovely region is atrociously poor and its few scattered farms.”

questions.correct: “And then there are my favorites, the great woods that are sixteen and twenty years old. It makes my heart bleed to see one of those cut down.”

questions.article:
Morning in the Woods is a poem by Ashton Barrera written in 1976.

My friend and I, together in the woods,
No words uttered.
Silence was the dome of woven leaves,
From which slipped several chirpings
Of chickadee.
A glance exchanged,
Conversation seemed dispensable.

Amidst the tranquil milieu of the little woods,
My friend and I communed in wordlessness.
A tapestry of woven foliage enveloped us,
Yielding only sporadic glimpses of avian melodies
Chorused by the petite chickadee.
A fleeting exchange of glances
Rendered our discourse seemingly superfluous.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It implies that the speaker and his friend don't trust each other.

options.name: B
options.content: It reflects a mood of melancholy in the speaker’s mind.

options.name: C
options.content: It demonstrates that the harmony between birds and nature aligns with the tacit understanding between the speaker and his friend.

options.name: D
options.content: It presents a contrasting feeling of the speaker toward the nature and his life.

questions.correct: It demonstrates that the harmony between birds and nature aligns with the tacit understanding between the speaker and his friend.

questions.article:
The following text is from Sara Teasdale's 1922 poem "Two Songs for Solitude."

Let them think I love them more than I do,

Let them think I care, though I go alone,

If it lifts their pride, what is it to me

Who am self-complete as a flower or a stone?
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: The speaker illustrates the importance of self-confidence and then explains how it helped her in several cases.

options.name: B
options.content: The speaker is sad about the lack of understanding among people around her and then expresses a desire to connect with them.

options.name: C
options.content: The speaker presents herself as fiercely independent and then recounts scenarios that demonstrate that independence.

options.name: D
options.content: The speaker lists various impressions people might have of her and then explains why they don't matter to her.

questions.correct: The speaker lists various impressions people might have of her and then explains why they don't matter to her.

questions.article: When expressing temporal concepts, individuals often utilize an egocentric frame of reference, employing spatial directions to denote time. For instance, when discussing past events, it is customary to point toward the left using the left hand, while discussions of future occurrences typically involve pointing toward the right with the right hand, thus establishing a self-centered framework of reference. Situated on the island of Papua New Guinea, there exists a primordial tribal community known as the Yupno tribe. Some scholars claim that the egocentric referencing is common across all human races, thus the Yupno people also adopt an egocentric frame of reference, using spatial indicators to represent time.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly undermine the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: The Yupno use their left hand to point to the right when talking about the future and use their left hand to point to the left when talking about the past.

options.name: B
options.content: The Yupno always use their left hand to point to the right or the left when denoting future or past events.

options.name: C
options.content: When referring to the future with backs towards the top of a hill, the Yupno point backward; when referring to the future while standing toward the top of a hill, the Yupno point to the front.

options.name: D
options.content: When referring to the future, the Yupno shake their heads to the left; when referring to the past, the Yupno shake their heads to the right.

questions.correct: When referring to the future with backs towards the top of a hill, the Yupno point backward; when referring to the future while standing toward the top of a hill, the Yupno point to the front.

questions.article: Veronica L. Bura, Akito Y. Kawahara, and Jayne E. Yack investigated the evolution and function of sound production in silk moth and hawk moth caterpillars. They found that during harmless simulated attacks on isolated caterpillars, 33% of the tested species produced sound, which ranged from clicks in Antheraea pernyi to whistles in Phyllosphingia dissimilis. Although some insects use sound to communicate with members of the same species, the researchers claim that the caterpillar sounds recorded in their study are directed primarily at predators.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Bura and colleagues’ claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Caterpillar clicks were emitted in a frequency detectable by birds that prey on caterpillars, but caterpillar whistles were not.

options.name: B
options.content: Each caterpillar species tended to produce one sound during simulated attacks, although individuals occasionally made a variety of other sounds during simulated attacks as well.

options.name: C
options.content: Chickens and yellow warblers, two predators of caterpillars, have been observed to stop their attacks in response to caterpillar sounds.

options.name: D
options.content: In most cases, the sound that a caterpillar species produced during simulated attacks was not produced by other caterpillar species during simulated attacks.

questions.correct: Chickens and yellow warblers, two predators of caterpillars, have been observed to stop their attacks in response to caterpillar sounds.

questions.article: In dialects of English spoken in Scotland, the “r” sound is strongly emphasized when it appears at the end of syllable (as in “car”) or before other consonant sounds (as in “bird”). English dialects of the Upland South, a region stretching from Oklahoma to western Virginia, place similar emphasis on “r” at the ends of syllables and before other consonant sounds. Historical records show that the Upland South was colonized largely by people whose ancestors came from Scotland. Thus linguists have concluded that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: the English dialects spoken in the Upland South acquired their emphasis on the “r” sound from dialects spoken in Scotland.

options.name: B
options.content: emphasis on the “r” sound will eventually spread from English dialects spoken in the Upland South to dialects spoken elsewhere.

options.name: C
options.content: the English dialects spoken in Scotland were influenced by dialects spoken in the Upland South.

options.name: D
options.content: people from Scotland abandoned their emphasis on the “r” sound after relocating to the Upland South.

questions.correct: the English dialects spoken in the Upland South acquired their emphasis on the “r” sound from dialects spoken in Scotland.

questions.article: What makes the theremin a unique musical instrument? You play it without touching it. When you place your ______ the pitch will shift as your hands move through the air.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: hand’s between the two antenna’s,

options.name: B
options.content: hands between the two antennas,

options.name: C
options.content: hands’ between the two antennas’,

options.name: D
options.content: hands’ between the two antennas,

questions.correct: hands between the two antennas,

questions.article: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) tracks comparative price list data for its thirty-eight member countries. According to this data, in July 2021, a “basket” of goods and services priced at 100 US dollars (USD) in the United States would have cost 82 USD in fellow OECD member ______
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: nation: South Korea.

options.name: B
options.content: nation South Korea.

options.name: C
options.content: nation, South Korea.

options.name: D
options.content: nation—South Korea.

questions.correct: nation South Korea.

questions.article: Thoreau Chapter is one of the 110 chapters of the Navajo Nation (Naabeehó Bináhásdzó). The chapter, known as Dioi Yachi in the Navajo language (Dine bizaad), was the subject of a profile ______ in the Navajo Times on May 8, 2014.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: appearing

options.name: B
options.content: appears

options.name: C
options.content: has appeared

options.name: D
options.content: appeared

questions.correct: appearing

questions.article: Juab High School and Park City High School are two of several Utah ______ enormous geoglyph of the letter J overlooks Juab High, while a geoglyph of the letters PC overlooks Park City High.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: schools that have their own hillside geoglyphs, an

options.name: B
options.content: schools, that have their own hillside geoglyphs and an

options.name: C
options.content: schools that have their own hillside geoglyphs. An

options.name: D
options.content: schools, that have their own hillside geoglyphs, and an

questions.correct: schools that have their own hillside geoglyphs. An

questions.article: Deposits of crushed volcanic rock and other organic matter lend the sand at Muriwai Reach in New Zealand an unusual black tint that dazzles ______ visitors. When they take a bit of sand home, though, it disturbs the beach’s ecosystem by contributing to erosion.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: visitors when

options.name: B
options.content: visitors, when

options.name: C
options.content: visitors. When

options.name: D
options.content: visitors and when

questions.correct: visitors. When

questions.article: Consider the mechanics of the pinhole camera: light passes through a small hole, resulting in a focused projected image. A ray diagram reveals how this ______ the hole’s small size restricts light to a single ray, all light passing through the hole can only arrive at a single destination, eliminating diffraction and ensuring a clear image.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: works because

options.name: B
options.content: works. Because

options.name: C
options.content: works, it’s because

options.name: D
options.content: works: it’s because

questions.correct: works. Because

questions.article: In 1949, Frank Zamboni developed an ice rink resurfacing machine. As Zamboni's machine moved along the rink's surface, it first scraped off the top layer of ice. ______ it sprayed water into the deep grooves left behind by customers' skates. Lastly, it smoothed over the newly formed ice.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: Next,

options.name: C
options.content: Similarly,

options.name: D
options.content: In contrast,

questions.correct: Next,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A lever is a simple machine consisting of a rigid beam and a fulcrum.
  • The fulcrum is the point about which the beam pivots.
  • The input force (effort) is the force applied to the lever.
  • The output force (load) is the force that the lever exerts on another object.
  • In first-class levers, the fulcrum is located between the effort and the load.
  • In second-class levers, the load is located between the effort and the fulcrum.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast first-class levers and second-class levers. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In levers, the effort is the force applied to the lever; the load, in contrast, is the force that the lever exerts on another object.

options.name: B
options.content: In first-class and second-class levers, the fulcrum and the load are in different locations.

options.name: C
options.content: First-class levers are simple machines consisting of a rigid beam and a fulcrum, but then again, the same is true of second-class lever.

options.name: D
options.content: In first-class levers, the fulcrum is located between the effort and the load, but in second-class levers, the load is located between the effort and the fulcrum.

questions.correct: In first-class levers, the fulcrum is located between the effort and the load, but in second-class levers, the load is located between the effort and the fulcrum.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Richard Serra is an American artist.
  • He is known for his large metal sculptures.
  • His large sculpture Through is made of forged steel.
  • His large sculpture TTI London is made of weathering steel.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize a difference between the two sculptures?

options.name: A
options.content: Artist Richard Serra is the creator of the forged steel sculpture Through.

options.name: B
options.content: TTI London is one of artist Richard Serra’s large metal sculptures.

options.name: C
options.content: Through is made from a different kind of steel than TTI London.

options.name: D
options.content: Through and TTI London are both large metal sculptures by artist Richard Serra.

questions.correct: Through is made from a different kind of steel than TTI London.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Maya Lin is an American artist known for her memorials and large-scale installation artworks.
  • She became famous in 1982 when she completed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, which consists of two 246-foot granite walls.
  • She completed Above and Below in 2007.
  • It is an installation composed of aluminum tubing that fills an entire gallery ceiling.
  • She completed Silver Upper White River in 2015.
  • It is an installation composed of recycled silver that fills an entire gallery wall.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize a difference between Above and Below and Silver Upper White River?

options.name: A
options.content: Maya Lin is known for her memorials and installation art, such as Above and Below and Silver Upper White River.

options.name: B
options.content: Maya Lin’s Above and Below is composed of aluminum tubing; Silver Upper White River, by contrast, is composed of recycled silver.

options.name: C
options.content: The sprawling size of Maya Lin’s Vietnam Veterans Memorial is echoed in Above and Below, a work made of aluminum tubing that fills an entire gallery ceiling.

options.name: D
options.content: After completing the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Maya Lin completed Above and Below, another large-scale work.

questions.correct: Maya Lin’s Above and Below is composed of aluminum tubing; Silver Upper White River, by contrast, is composed of recycled silver.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A supercontinent is a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth’s continents.
  • Over time, continents merge together to form supercontinents, which then break apart.
  • This process is believed to take hundreds of millions of years and is known as the supercontinent cycle.
  • Ur and Gondwana were supercontinents.
  • Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.
  • Gondwana formed about 510 million years ago.
questions.question: The student wants to specify when Ur formed. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Long ago, the Earth was home to supercontinents like Ur and Gondwana.

options.name: B
options.content: The supercontinent Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.

options.name: C
options.content: Ur was a supercontinent, a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth’s continents.

options.name: D
options.content: Over hundreds of millions of years, the supercontinent cycle results in supercontinents forming and breaking apart.

questions.correct: The supercontinent Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Casa Luis Barragán (1948) is a residential home designed by Mexican architect Luis Barragán.
  • It is located in Mexico City, Mexico.
  • It features colorful concrete walls and a famous cantilevered staircase.
  • It is considered an impressive example of minimalist architecture.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the location of Casa Luis Barragán?

options.name: A
options.content: The architect responsible for designing Casa Luis Barragán.

options.name: B
options.content: A stunning example of minimalist architecture, Luis Barragán‘s Casa Luis Barragán features colorful concrete walls and a famous cantilevered staircase.

options.name: C
options.content: Luis Barragán is known for designing a residential home that features colorful concrete walls and a famous cantilevered staircase.

options.name: D
options.content: Those wishing to see Casa Luis Barragán in person will have to travel to Mexico City, Mexico.

questions.correct: Those wishing to see Casa Luis Barragán in person will have to travel to Mexico City, Mexico.
